word.entryDescription: (for a computer or a computer system) to suddenly stop working properly due to a software malfunction
word.entryExample: My computer has crashed.

word.entryDescription: an accident in which a car or plane hits something else or hits the ground
word.entryExample: 80 people were killed in the plane crash.

word.entryDescription: stupid or not sensible; mad
word.entryExample: What a crazy idea!

word.entryDescription: the thick high-fat part of milk
word.entryExample: No thank you, I won't have any cream, but I'll have a cup of tea, please.

word.entryDescription: to put pressure on something/somebody because they have too much or something difficult to manage; worry that this produces
word.entryExample: Many campaigners worry that it will create a strain on public services and resources such as water.

word.entryDescription: producing original or unusual ideas
word.entryExample: He's creative, he loves painting and drawing.

word.entryDescription: a plastic card issued by a company which agrees to pay for what you are buying, and you pay them back later
word.entryExample: Do you accept credit cards?

word.entryDescription: a document that a shop gives to you (e.g. when you have returned goods) allowing you to have other goods of the same value in exchange
word.entryExample: She suggested that I exchange the suit for another one, or accept a credit note so I can spend the money on something else from your shop.

word.entryDescription: a team sport in which people hit a ball with a long wide bat and then run between two sets of wooden posts
word.entryExample: Can you play cricket?

word.entryDescription: an illegal act
word.entryExample: I like thrillers, especially those with a crime to solve.

word.entryDescription: a location where a crime was committed, comprising the area from which most of the physical evidence is collected
word.entryExample: It often takes months or even years to investigate all the evidence from a crime scene.

word.entryDescription: a person who commits a crime
word.entryExample: Are the police considered an effective force against criminals?

word.entryDescription: a crime, an activity that is illegal
word.entryExample: What we are dealing here with is a criminal act.

word.entryDescription: very thin slice of potato fried in oil and eaten as a snack
word.entryExample: My favourite food used to be ice cream, but now it's crisps.

word.entryDescription: a large animal with a long mouth and sharp teeth that lives in and near water
word.entryExample: Do crocodiles live in water?

word.entryDescription: to go from one side to the other
word.entryExample: You can't cross the road here!

word.entryDescription: to draw a line through or make a dark mark over something (e.g. a mistake) that is written
word.entryExample: They need a rubber so that they don't spend all day crossing out mistakes in their work.

word.entryDescription: extremely important
word.entryExample: Water is crucial for life.

word.entryDescription: deliberately causing pain, suffering, sadness, etc
word.entryExample: She is a cruel girl.

word.entryDescription: press something so hard that it breaks into small pieces
word.entryExample: The seeds are dried and fermented in the sun, then dried in an oven and crushed in a mill.

word.entryDescription: to produce tears from your eyes, usually because you are unhappy or hurt
word.entryExample: The baby is crying.

word.entryDescription: a long vegetable with a green skin and a soft watery flesh
word.entryExample: I don't like cucumber in salad.

word.entryDescription: the final result of a process or situation
word.entryExample: The working model was the culmination of many months of hard work.

word.entryDescription: the arts: painting, music, literature, film, etc
word.entryExample: I can learn much more about Russia culture.

word.entryDescription: a small container with a handle (a thing you hold something with) that you drink from
word.entryExample: Here's a cup for your tea, Lucy.

word.entryDescription: the last and most important match in a competition that gives a cup (prize) to the winners
word.entryExample: The doctor wants William to play in the cup final.

word.entryDescription: a small container usually with a handle containing tea
word.entryExample: I'm going to visit grandma and have a cup of tea with her.

word.entryDescription: a piece of furniture like a large tall box with doors at the front and shelves inside
word.entryExample: Put the shopping in the cupboard.

word.entryDescription: something, i.e a medicine or medical treatment, that cures an illness
word.entryExample: Today scurvy is much less common, but the cure is simple: eat more fruit!

word.entryDescription: to make an illness or other medical condition go away
word.entryExample: Thanks to medical science, some diseases have been completely cured.

word.entryDescription: curly hair has a lot of curves and round shapes, not straight
word.entryExample: Ann has black curly hair.

word.entryDescription: a dish from South Asia made from meat or vegetables in a spicy sauce
word.entryExample: Which would you prefer: chicken curry and rice or meatballs and tomato sauce?

word.entryDescription: a cloth which you hang over a window to stop people looking in or to block light
word.entryExample: If it all gets too much and you need some privacy, there are curtains that you can use to separate some areas of the house.

word.entryDescription: a shape or line which isn't straight, but bends
word.entryExample: Experts examine the curves and marks left behind when things are touched and compare them with the marks and curves on the fingers of a suspect.

word.entryDescription: a bag filled with soft material used to make you more comfortable when sitting
word.entryExample: I suggest taking a cushion to sit on.

word.entryDescription: somebody who buys something from a business
word.entryExample: The assistant gives the customer a refund.

word.entryDescription: to separate something or break the surface of something with a sharp edge
word.entryExample: The farm cuts the wool of the sheep in the spring time.

word.entryDescription: to make something fall down
word.entryExample: Forests are being cut down to create more space for people.

word.entryDescription: to reduce the amount of something you do, eat, etc, often in order to improve your health
word.entryExample: You should eat less fatty food and you need to cut down on your sugar.

word.entryDescription: to separate something from something larger by cutting
word.entryExample: I went upstairs to his wardrobe, got his best suit and cut off the arms!

word.entryDescription: to make something by cutting
word.entryExample: Milliners have to cut out the material before they can make a hat.

word.entryDescription: sold at a price that is cheaper than usual
word.entryExample: I just adore finding cut price designer goods!

word.entryDescription: pleasant and attractive – especially of something or someone small or young
word.entryExample: Look at these cute ducks!

word.entryDescription: a document listing your personal details, education, work experience, etc, which you write and send to employers when looking for a job
word.entryExample: CV stands for Curriculum Vitae – the story of your life.

word.entryDescription: knowledge of how to be safe online, protect your private information and protect yourself from computer crime
word.entryExample: I'm worried about her cyber safety. I don't know who she's talking to.

word.entryDescription: bullying someone by sending them nasty messages or saying mean things about them online
word.entryExample: Most of us are expert social media users nowadays, but few people know how to avoid online crime and cyberbullying.

word.entryDescription: a sport in which you ride bikes
word.entryExample: We often go cycling around the lake.

word.entryDescription: somebody who rides a bicycle
word.entryExample: Who is the greatest cyclist?

word.entryDescription: relating to milk and foods made from milk; connected with production of milk
word.entryExample: Yoghurt is a kind of dairy food.

word.entryDescription: a small, white flower with a yellow centre, that often grows in areas of grass
word.entryExample: Daisies are small pretty flowers.
